Today, Wat Arun stands as a prominent landmark on the Thonburi side of the Chao Phraya and bears some of the hallmark designs of the Ayutthaya temple architecture.

column1: Stunning by day and by night

Wat Arun, is a 'must see' for anyone visiting Bangkok. My wife and I visited as part of an "Introduction to Bangkok" Tour, operated by Exo Travel Thailand. We pre-booked this with our Travel Agent, Trailfinders, prior to leaving the UK and that was worth doing. Our guide picked us up at our hotel and took us around the city, using various modes of transport, and visiting all of the most important sightseeing places. His knowledge of every place visited was invaluable, and saved us having to stop regularly to read up on the history of each place.

Although the central Prang is stunning, and the main feature in Wat Arun, there are other parts worth seeing. such as the main Chapel and the Ordination Hall. Wat Arun is normally visited during daylight hours, it is worth returning at night, if only to take photos when it is lit up. My wife and I were able to do that, as we booked a second tour, also with Exo, that included 'Bangkok by Night' and a riverside dinner. This gave us the chance to take photos in both daylight and nighttime and I will upload photos of both.

This is why going with a knowledgeable guide is such an advantage, as the names and history of each part are explained to you, saving invaluable time if you wish to visit other popular sights on the same day.

In Thai the word Wat translates to temple and Arun means dawn. Thus this temple is known in English as the Temple of Dawn. This is a very popular attraction for many tourists along with the Grand Palace which is located directly across the river from Wat Arun by downtown Bangkok. To get to Wat Arun you will need to board a ferry to take you across the river. The easiest way to get to one would be to board the Bangkok Transit System (BTS) and get off on the Saphan Taksin ferry stop. From there it is around 25 minutes via boat to Wat Arun with some stops along the way. There will be signs at the dock listing tourist boats but beware that many will try to overcharge. For two individuals you shouldn’t pay more than 100 THB one way. If you choose to board at a different location they may charge upwards of 350 THB per person in locations near the Grand Palace. If you are near there we suggest walking down 10 minutes to the Tha Thien ferry station and pay 4 THB per person instead. Once you arrive you will purchase an entry ticket for 50 THB and if you are not dressed properly they will allow you to rent a sarong for 20 THB with a 100 THB refundable deposit. Generally you should wear long pants and avoid showing open shoulders but they can be lenient at times. Once inside you are free to roam around but there will be security there who will warn you if you are doing something you aren’t supposed to. This is mainly to protect the temple as many people tend to climb on the structures to get a good picture. We highly advise visiting here especially If you are torn between this and the Grand Palace.

Wat Arun is a Buddhist temple in Bangkok (west bank of the Chao Phraya River). The Temple of the Dawn towering over the Chao Phraya River is one of Bangkok’s most visually striking landmarks and also one of Thailand’s top attractions. The temple was built in 17th century in the era of the Ayutthaya Kingdom. The temple’s name has taken from the Hindu god “Aruna”.
The temple’s central prang stands 79 meters tall and is decorated with tiny pieces of colored glittery glass. The first rays of the morning sun in Bangkok appear on the surface of the temple vividly.
If you don’t want to be stuck in the crowd and you want to take full pleasure of the sunrise in the temple go there as soon as possible. You must wear respectable clothes for entering the holy temple, otherwise you have to pay money to borrow suitable clothes from the temple’s entrance.
Wat Arun can be easily accessed through the Chao Phraya River by taxi boats which travel across the river. If you take a longtail boat tour for visiting Bangkok, you can see both Wat Arun and Bangkok’s other top attractions such as Chinatown, Wat Phra Kaew, Grand Palace and the Wat Pho, as you cruising the Chao Phraya River. Visiting of this really magnificent temple is highly recommended.

Every thing in thai. Why. You want foreigners money only. Trust me. It's just fold buildings and statues.

If you are in Bangkok, you simply must visit this temple. I recommend arriving by boat. By car is pretty hectic, as the Bangkok roads are pretty lawless. I avoid tuk Tuks whenever possible in this country.
Great Palace to visit when you are in Bangkok close to riverside of chaoprya river the temple of dawn
Very beautiful place and defenetly worth your time. If you want good photos I recommend that you should go there around 9-11am.

One of the few things that worth to see in Bangkok and worth to pay for.
Easy to reach to it (I would recommend boat for only 4 baht).
This temple is made of ceramic and is just gorgeous. We visited with a guide but it would be easy to just walk through and marvel at the beauty.

It is also one of the few temples that predates the founding of Bangkok and the start of the Rattanakosin era in 1782. It’s prang dominated the skyline around the Chao Phraya river during the early days of Bangkok and today is still one of the most impressive sights on the river.

After the destruction of the former capital Ayutthaya by the Burmese in 1767, King Taksin the Great established Thonburi on the West bank of the Chao Phraya river as the new capital.

The temple is one of the most famous views in Bangkok and lit up at night. The temple in itself is pnly accesible on the outside and to be honest it´s more impressive from a distance than close-up. If visiting then there are other impressive and less famous temples surrounding it which shouldn´t be missed. Access is easy with one of the river boats which all stop by here.

Wat Arun/ The Temple of Dawn is a beautiful structure across the river from central Bangkok, and features incredible mosaics of broken porcelain. Well worth the visit before a tour of the canals. BKK tours Nadia provided much insight. Loved the mural sized photos of King Rama X and Queen Sirikit.
Seeing it up close during the day is good, but seeing it at dusk and in the dark is just wonderful. Some lovely viewing spots easily reachable in a Grab taxi directly opposite.

I had visited this temple 2 times. Once i was at restaurant across the river. Sip some juice and enjoy the moment when sun dawns. Take your time for this moment.
Again I went to temple to see it closely. It is impressive details. I love local vibes.

But if you are not that types of person. Just sip and sit at the bar , look at the temple . It is worth for your time in Bangkok

column1: One of most beautiful temples in Bangkok
column3:
The Wat Arun is easy to reach by HopOn HopOff Boat and is directly loacted at the Pier. Even the Wat Arun lokks already impressive from far, when you see the details in close, it is really impressive. Only drawback now, it is not allowed anymore to climb up the rather dangerous stairs From there was a good view to the Chao Phraya.
No need of long trousers necessary, just covered shoulders. Best to go there in late afternoon, less tourists and very beautiful light ambiance in sunset.

We approached Wat Arun from the river, which was an impressive way to see this temple for the first time. You must be dressed appropriately for visiting this temple. There are also quite a few steps to be climbed up if you want to get up to the 2nd level, which is as far as you are allowed to visit. The decoration of the temple is wonderful with lovely mosaics and statues. Definitely worth a visit
Relaxing place and good to explore on your own. You can take a cheap ferry ride across the river and enjoy this view while sitting at some riverside cafe.
Awesome. That is incredibly great experience and i wanna share it with my friends, hopefully i can comeback someday with them.

Great visit. Make sure you dress appropriately but there are things to can rent for a few if you aren’t prepared. There a a few steps involved, but you can still enjoy it even if you don’t go all the way up!
It’s an ok visit. Pay 50 baht for it. Not a big temple like wat pho but still you will have a wonderful picture there.

Even though it was crowded at the time I visited this temple, but I liked the boat trip which I started from Saphan Taksin. The water journey was quite adventurous in those muddy water with lots of boats, ferries and speed boats cruising in, makes us feel that we are in a water theme park 😬..
But once we reach the Temple, it’s all different. The locals people are in the holy mood and tourists enjoy the sculptures, architectural beauty of the temple and those rock paved ways. You certainly should walk bare feet to feel those black rocks giving a natural massage. The view inside the temple is like any other in Bangkok with a massive idol of Buddha. The view from the temple is scenic, overlooking Phraya river and skyscrapers on the other side.
But it’s really worth taking time to visit the place once you are in Bangkok.
Very impressive landmark, and worth of visiting. Not necessarily the most suitable for families with small children, in my opinion.

column1: Nice sight which won't take too long
column3: Wat Arun is a very nice temple and a quick stop long the river. If you take some time to take a close look the colours are very beautiful. Easy to cross the river by ferry to see some other sites.

On of the best spot for Bangkok old town top view by the river. The mosaic exterior is exceptional and photogenic.

Please watch out while going up as the stairs are quite steep.

The best time to go is during sunrise when tourists are few.

Amazing place that you just have to see. Make sure that you wear appropriate clothing, although they will rent you something if needed. The design and architecture is stunning.

Best way to get there is by the ferry crossing from Tha Tien to Wat Arun at 4 Baht per person. Ignore the Tut Tut guys who tell you that places such as the Royal Palace are closed until 1pm, total rubbish.

column1: one of the best spot in Bangkok
column3: I've been in Bangkok about 15 times in my life, and Wat Arun is always a must to visit place every time. This temple is very different from all the other ones you can find around Thailand, and it is in amazing at dawn with the sun setting behind the temple. You can drink a cocktail or eat a full lunch in one of the restaurant on the other side of the river in front of Wat Arun
A magnificent Temple on the riverside. Easily accessible by river ferries. Not to be missed. Best viewed from across the river at sunset.
The decor was really great. A must do visit. We went by hop on the ferry very easily. The scenery here is very beautiful and poetic

Like a number of the temple sites in Bangkok this is really amazing. The colours, the architecture the peacefulness of the actual temples is wonderful. This is quite a large site with a number of courtyards and buildings to visit with some terrific sculptures. The entry fee for the temple at 50baht is very good value. Of importance to many people, the toilet facilities are clean and good (a contribution of 5Baht to use them is suggested). We spent a good hour wandering round the site and could probably have stayed longer.
You cannot visit Bangkok without seeing the Temple of Dawn. Incredible architecture and experience overall!

The scenery here is very beautiful and poetic, especially at night with the orange-yellow light surrounding the temple, making it extravagant, combined with ancient architecture makes it more majestic and mysterious. More than that, it’s wonderful that I have come to a place like this in my wife

This is a visit that should be done while in Bangkok. Just sheer opulence the scale of the Tempe of Dawn is huge you could spend hours taking in the beauty of the construction. The decorations are truly amazing. A must do visit. We went by hop on Ferry very easy.
It's so big you would need 3 days. Make sure you see all the different makers. There is an animal section, food section, souvenirs section and absolutely don't forget the art section!
Very pretty and nice temple. We seen it at night and the reclining budda closes at 6pm. Lit up at night it is very surreal, and calm. Go see it.
Good nice plice too have foon and smile and very good food and drink for the bankok and the cyti center

Came here at high noon and probably a hot mistake. Fewer tourists due to the virus and maybe also the heat. You can’t climb all the way to the top but still lots of photo opportunities. This temple is about 300 years old and you can get here by taxi/grab or boat as it’s just by the river

Wear longish shorts so you don’t have to rent or buy anything outside. And the entry fee doubles from 50 to 100 baht from 1 june 2020

column1: Cheap entry, Amazing structure- worth it
column3: Overall a good experience. 50 Baht entry which is about £1 (just over $1) is not bad at all. Very intricate structure, good history behind it. There's a shuttle bus to the reclining Buddha for 4 Baht which is basically free. Which was good too. Would recommend.
This is a must visit. my favourite temple and stunning both day and night so make sure you visit twice!

No words can describe the amazing ornate temple of Wat Arun. Set against the Chao Phraya river, it’s Thai history and beauty at its best. Don’t miss visiting while you are in Bangkok. Compared to a few of the other temples it’s only a small 50 baht each per entry.

column1: Perfect balance of religion, history and beauty
column3:
One of Thailand's best-known landmarks, seen at its best at sunrise, sunset or when illuminated at night.

Located on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River, it was once within the grounds of the Royal Palace during the reign of King Taksin and enshrined the Emerald Buddha. King Rama I moved the Royal Palace to the east bank and the Emerald Buddha to Wat Phra Kaew within its grounds, where both can be found to this day.

The best way from central Bangkok to What Arun is to take the BTS to Saphan Taksin station, take the north west Exit 1, continue to walk west to Sathorn Pier, take the river boat to Tha Tian Pier, Pier 8, and then take the ferry across the river.

If you go in the evening, on your return to Tha Tien Pier there are a number of bars/restaurants with roof-top views of Wat Arun from across the river.
Even though we went after it closed, we could still admire the beauty of Wat Arun outside of the gates. Once it was illuminated, another dimension was added to it.
Good for an afternoon activity to explore this temple and take some photos around the area. Also check out the river cruise nearby
I got to see the temple of Dawn from a boat tour on the river in the middle of bangkok. The boat operator was great enough to get us nice and close. It's quite a nice view from the river.
we had 1 night in BKK and went on a cruise and passed the Wat Arun during the day which was stunning from the boat. Wish we stopped but a great landmark in Bangkok

column1: Great place - go by ferry from the Grand Palace
column3:
Wat Arun

Temple, temple and more temples. It’s what you come to Thailand for & this one is just as beautiful as the rest.

To get there the tourist boat stops outside of there is a little ferry boat (4 baht per person) which shuttles people from one side of the river to the other.

We went later on in the day about 1600 and it was really nice to wander round. There isn’t anywhere to go inside but you can climb onto it and walk all the way round. It didn’t take us very long at all to take some photos and get round it.

We would definitely recommend coming back at night as you can get a cracking views and it’s lit up beautifully. The little restaurants and bars on the opposite side of the river to it are some of the best places to see it from.

It’s definitely one to see but if you are short on time you can see it from the river or from the other side you wouldn’t necessarily be missing out but not stopping and climbing onto it.

column1: A must do if in Bangkok
column3:
We visited here after walking for about 20 mins from Kao San area and getting the ferry across, which is cheap.
Entry to Wat Arun is 50 Baht at time of writing, but I think this is going up to 100 Baht during 2020.
It is much quieter than the Grand Palace and it takes around 30 mins to walk around completely.
We did it during the day at around 9:30am.
Architecturally it is absolutely fantastic to see, and some of the paintings of various stones and art work really is brilliant.
I’m sure this place means a lot to some people who we saw praying. We didn’t obviously feel the same appreciation probably because we aren’t religious, however we could certainly appreciate others’ love for Wat Arun.
Tips - bring water as expensive nearby, and wear long pants for both men and women.

Different by day and night this is definitely worth making time for on your trip to Bangkok

If you wish to climb up to the first section where further access above has been cut off then the steps can be a little step so not good for elderly or people with balance or height issues

Fascinating temple though
Definitely a must see on any visit. It only takes 30 minutes or so to walk around after getting the ferry across the river for 4 baht
Absolute must see in Bankok - it is a wonder and is worth the visit. Don’t forget your sin team and hate and a dam good camera.
Amazing construction! Color and reflection created with recycled plates and dishes from China. A must see if in Bangkok, early morning and at night.

Wat Arun is located in a not too big area. The temple has an amazing architecture, and decorated with colorful ceramics all over the wall. Women usually love this... just like me. Some ceramics formed as flowers, it is amazing to see how patient the people build each temple. For reaching this temple you need to take BTS to Sampan Taksin station and buy a boat ticket for THB 60 each way.

This is a must see attraction in Bangkok, and is a very beautiful temple on the banks of the river. On a hop-on hop-off boat ride, this is one of the stops which surely should be taken. Entry is 50 Baht but worth it. If you want to do some quick shopping, things are available at a pretty cheap price.
Beautiful view from the daily cruise at sunset time. Make sure to book in advance and check the boats to avoid the crowds.
I think I l didthis already but just in case. Awesome place and well worth the quest wherever your coming from. Pretty awesome.
Beautiful shrine! You can climb some steps AND go around. There Is a little market outside, with very good prices. You can cross the River by public boat, 14 baths Kids love it!

Impressive sight.
not very big but beautiful.
I was sad not to be able to walk to top as it was locked..shut....not allowed only the lower part we could walk.
still lovely tho. worth a visit

We took a taxi at night to Wat Arun. The grounds are open and uncrowded, although we were a little nervous as it is off of a side street and no one was around the area. We did however have no problem finding a tuk-tuk on the main street afterwards, although they did charge us a premium - don't forget to bargain. But it was beautiful at night and we were very happy to have made the effort.
Fantastic place and lots to see will be back again hopefully soon been a long time since I have been. Would love to go back

column1: Icon of Thailand; My Favorite Temple
column3: Prominently located on the Chao Phraya River, with its image on the reverse of the 10 Baht coin, this is my favorite temple in Thailand. Referred to as the Temple of Dawn, both sunrise and sunset plays beautifully off the light colored surface. Following the fall of Ayutthaya in 1768, King Taksin felt that this would be the perfect location for the new capital upon encountering the old temple "Wat Magog". He renamed it "Wat Jaeng" (Temple of Dawn); which King Rama IV renamed Wat Arunratchawararam; now simply: "Wat Arun". The Emerald Buddha was housed here until both the capital and the Emerald Buddha were later relocated to the far safer Rattanakosin Island, directly across the river. The spires (prang) were added in the early 19th century. There are several buildings to tour here with exquisite tiles and gold details, but the main "Wat" does require a small fee. This is a Buddhist Temple, so observe the dress code with men in long pants and shirts with sleeves. Women should have their shoulders covered, as well as their knees. There are numerous shopping stalls in the area for clothing and gifts, as well as places to grab a snack or refreshment. Arrive early to beat the crowds. The grounds are lovely to explore, or you could even rent a traditional Thai outfit for a photograph before one of the buildings. Easy to access by river ferry from Rattanakosin (Old City), or by public river boat. Do also view Wat Arun when it is illuminated at night, as it is absolutely stunning!

Really worth visiting .
Easy to find :-)
We traveled with kids.
Toilets nearby and stalls to buy long trousers or tops if you forget bring one.

From june 2020 Price goes up from 50 to 100 Bhat . Which is still cheap .

Great value temple at around £1 entry fee. Not as large as the Grand Palace or Wat Po but it’s just as lovely. The temple buildings are cream and covered in thousands of colourful decorations. Beware the steps are very steep with no handrails to hold.
So many good spots to take pictures, you must wear a proper clothes, no short skirt, no tank tops, to honor the place. wonderful lighting in the evening. you should bring your camera

Our visit to Temple of Dawn was great ; the ticket for the visit was cheap and the views there are fabulous. a friend of us was there and told us to do ;all I can say is that everything was fantastic.

column1: Dawn Temple but best in the evening
column3:
We went there by car. Then took the ferry. About 4 Baht per head. The entrance to the ferry looks a bit shady or dodgy but it isn't really. Just not properly signposted or official looking enough. Initially thought it was a diversion scam. The ferry is NOT over loaded...and waiting time,even if you fail to catch it, is only a few minutes...there are small souvenir stalls here so even waiting is a pleasure. The ferry-ride is just about 2 minutes or so...over before it really begins.
Totally speechless at first sight of the Temple complex. Exquisite is what comes to mind. Lovely lawns. Small souvenir and refreshment stalls too.
Apparently they used a million ceramic tiles from a Chinese shipwreck to decorate the facade. These were deftly incorporated into flowers and all! And when the sunlight hits it...the glitter is marvelous.
I would advise visitors to wear sensible shoes. And clothes that reflect your respect for the local culture and value system. . I wore a salwar kameez ...a saree would have been fine too...but was saddened to see that many people were not clad appropriately to visit a temple.
In the evening we went to a restaurant cum bar on the other side of the river to photograph the temple when it was all lit up. Against the fading light and colourful dusk sky with the illuminated boats on the river, the temple presented an unforgettable new look.
Wat Arun’s full name is Wat Arun Ratchawararam Ratchawaramahawihan... a small sum is payable for entry...and entry is about 8.30 Am onwards ...don't say I never told you!

ON our previous visits, we just viewed this temple from afar but this time, I was able to enter the temple and view it up close. It is so beautiful. The details on the temple are exquisite and it becomes even more beautiful at night when it is lighted. We did not climb to the upper part because the stairs were so steep. Had to be contented with taking photos from the middle level.
Amazing. So much history. Deserves to be a 7 Wonder of the World. use a guide - you learn more! Go early as it gets very hot in the afternoon. History like this needs to be preserved and seen.
10 am and the place was packed with people. It a great structure and gorgeous to look at . Just be prepared to fight the crowd for a decent photo.
You have to go to this joint as it just reeks of history and charm that one can have access to. Truly a gem and I wont spoil anything. definitely a eye opener!
Very nice temple. A beautiful architecture. One would fall in love with the masterpiece. Nice place to take beautiful pictures.
You're only spend 50 baht .Wat Arun is among the best know of Thailand's landmarks.The frist light of the morning reflects off the surface of the temple with pearly iridescence.I love this location

This wat is well worth a visit, but often seen and photographed from the river. Coated in colourful ceramic tiles it's even more interesting close up!
The Chao Phraya riverboat express stops here on its way to and from the Grand Palace. Steep steps up the sides of this wat need care, especially when descending.

A stunning Wat which is so totally different from the others we saw. The detail is so impressive - although the scale was also there at 82 metres in height. Limitations now exist in climbing The Spire. Ironically the out of bounds steps have handrails while the accessible lower ones do not. Still a magnificent site and well worth a visit even if you only walk around the structure and admire the detail.
Great to visit Wat Arun, we were there at day time and at dinner we sailed on Alangka cruise, appreciated our dinner with the view along Chao Praya river and Wat Arun by night was stunning

We jumped off a river excursion to visit this site although there is a land entry. The complex does charge admission but you can get a pretty close up view from outside. The intricate details of the structure are amazing.
The Temple of Dawn is awesome. It's all so very photogenic, so I would strongly recommend all my family and friends see it.

Like most other temples in Thailand, please dress appropriately with long pants and tops that cover your shoulders! If you do not, they will refuse your entrance into the temple. However, there are many shops at the ferry dock and before the temple grounds in case you forget. However, I think it's always better to be prepared!

After a short walk from the Grand Palace (around 15-20 minutes), you take a ferry to the temple. Ferry prices are around 4 THB/person. This ferry ride takes no longer than 5-10 minutes. At the temple, entrance fees are 100 THB per person (but I read a sign that stated the fee will be increased to 200 THB per person on June 2020).

Once you go in, it is an absolutely magical experience. The architecture is amazing. Visitors are able to climb up to the lower portion of the wat to see the architecture up close. However, be careful! The steps are very steep. I suggest going as early as possible to avoid the baking sun and crowds as much as possible. We were there before noon and it was already becoming very, VERY crowded. However, seeing this temple from up close is worth all the sweatiness and crowds we endured.

It is the most beautiful temple we ever visited. The attention to details is really overwelming, just beautiful beyond words ! You cannot see it from inside at dark time since it closes I believe at 6pm. But you appreciate the beauty at night hours from a boat or from across the river. Please visit, you won't be dissapointed.

Really nice area to see. The grounds and architecture are amazing. You can get some great views from here too. You can take the ferry across the river for only a couple Baht. Be sure to go early in the day before the sun is up and before it gets too crowded.

We were there in January 2020 - very hot. The intricacies of the tower are simply amazing. For the best photos you need to take them on the "sunny" side. Lots of people/tourists made it hard to get an isolated shot but c'est la vie. The area around the Wat includes a small souvenir market, toilets and a westerly section that has a long array of golden buddha statues. From our hotel window (Baan Wanglang) we watched the Wat light up just before dusk so we caught a Tuk Tuk to the Wat at about 9:00pm - this was well worth it - although the inner part of the Wat is closed there is still opportunity to walk around it for free.

We took the ferry across to Wat Arun. So beautiful. When we were done, there was a huge line for the ferry back across the river. The new MRT line goes across the river so we walked - 20 min to the Itsaraphap station (waiting on line would have taken an hour) and we took the MRT straight back.

You can walk around the lower tier of the main prang/tower/pagoda to see the porcelain tiles and statues up close. A truly wonderful experience. Not a large site so it can get crowded but doesn't take long.
A must see while in Bangkok. easy to get too. we visited during day and it was superb. but if you can, visit during night :)
Such an amazing place to see. The craftsmanship and history of Wat Arun temple is one not to miss. My only regret is not having enough time to stay longer. An hour isn’t enough
Check out Wat Arun up close, but definitely get a look at it at dawn and dusk across the Chao Phraya river. It's beautiful when lit up against the backdrop of sunrise and sunset.

To experience it, visitors can pay a small admission price to climb inside the temple's central prang, but keep in mind that the steps are steep and the stairway is very narrow. Many travelers rave about Wat Arun for its beauty and tranquility – that is if you get there before the crowds. Recent visitors report crowds here aren't as bad as they are at the Grand Palace or Wat Pho but it's still best to get here early if you want to experience the attraction at its most peaceful. No matter what time you go, be sure your knees and shoulders are covered. And depending on where you go in Wat Arun, you may be required to take your shoes off.
Beautiful temple to visit, especially at the sunset. I recommend that you eat across the temple perhaps at the following locations or at the best picture opportunity; suppanigga eating room

column1: Great Example of a Thai Temple Close to the city
column3: Great archutecture and within walking, ferry motorcycle taxi from other attractions. Well worth being a tourist to see this.
One of the most amazing things I have ever seen! This was my first visit to a Wat and i will never forget it. I took so many pictures that I can't decide which ones to place on canvas and hang.

Go to Wat Arun, it's a bit out of the way, unless you hop on a transit boat. It's definitely the most picturesque and photogenic of the temples in Bangkok. A beautiful place. We walked through neighborhoods to get there and I would encourage that as Bangkok is a cool city.

apart from the site is a cultural value and heritage reputation
As the country driven by tourism , there are lot of money laundering- cheating activities
been there January 2020 with family
A lady who agreed to have a round trip ( we paid in advance) vanished after dropping us (we lost around 100aud, But glad we are safe), we end up in paying private boat to go to the other side of the river
There are restriction for women , Surprisingly not men , women not allowed if they wear short dresses, But the options are costly too , you need to buy or rent clothes near by
There are opportunistic vendours everywhere ( Money transaction, Private boating)
Apart from the Thai people who are great in their hospitality , this is very unfortunate experience of mine

2/And don't trust the tuk-tuk fellas (taxi men is better than the tuk -tuk guys , comparatively)

Must go and see this fantastic building, it's beautiful, only 50bat to get in. Unfortunately I forgot to cover my shoulders up so wasn't allowed in, so just remember girls. But we could walk round the outside and there was other pray rooms you could see in the gardens. Only a few stops on the boat to get there.
I like this pagoda it look so beautiful in day and night. I try to find the door for go inside but it was close can not get in. So sad.
The temple itself was good .. enjoyed the architecture, but hey .. after seeing one temple after another, I was fairly well templed out

We toured the facility in about an hour. We enjoyed climbing the stairs and taking pictures. We did note the lack of printed information or signs about each object. While the entrance fee was cheaper than the other sites, we would gladly pay just a bit more for signs to explain what we’re looking at.
Definitely a must visit through. We caught a long boat from near our hotel for 100B and caught the local ferry on our way back for 4B.

column1: Recently renovated and in pristine condition
column3:
Wat Arun was recently restored and looks better than ever. Unfortunately you can no longer go far up the structure, but this is understandable bearing in mind the increase in visitors.

Best approached from the river. An iconic building that should not be missed. There are many other buildings behind Wat Arun that many visitors miss.
nice place , beautiful scene and amazing architecture.The temple is not so far from downtown area of Bangkok and feeling so fresh to cross the river by boat.

near wat pho and the royal palace, you can take a boat that cross the river for i think 7 baht. The entrance fee if i remember was around 50-100 baht. Beautiful architecture with intricate design. Nearby there is a less crowded temple where you can get a blessing from the monk on duty.
Just across the river this magnificent temple sits by the waters edge. Stunning construction using old pottery to give the amazing vision of wealth and prosperity. Only 50 baht to enter.
The temple is reachable via a ferry. The architecture is beautiful. Though the inner sanctum is closed for tourists, it is still worth a visit.
Go around 5pm - 5.30pm for the best lighting (sunset is beautiful.) it’s also when there are less crowds around!

The steps are very steep at this temple so be wArned but you can view it by walking around at ground level. Easy to get to by Hop on Off boats on the river. There is a small Market which was quite interesting and cheap

Getting to the Temple of Dawn is a treat - riding in an open boat on the Chao Praya river. Very cooling in Bangkok's heat and humidity.

It's not too congested either, so much easier to walk around and see all the details of the Temple.
Visited or tried to in 2015 before refurbishment - now refurbished with porcelain from China very different to previously - worth a visit to see the myriad of Chinese Thai and Vietnamese styles

Yeah so if you're visiting Bangkok this is one of the must see sights. We took a ferry up the river to get there and then had a walk around for maybe 90min. Probably don't need much more than that. Less than an hour is probably a rush. We then walked back along the bank of the river, can be large queues for the ferry back late afternoon

I have see few temples around Bangkok and this is definitely my favourite one.
The architecture and the decorations are so detailed!it might be crowded during the late afternoon but a visit here really worths it!

This is one of my favourite temples as it's covered in beautiful brightly coloured pieces of porcelain. the tops of each temple hold a warrior on a horse and there are different looking figures that line a layer of the temple. The symmetry of this temple is incredible with its different layers.
The size of this place is really huge. It was an amazing temple. Great to see this beautiful creation.
A must visit. Went with friend who, in the past climbed to the top. This is now closed off above the first level.
It was a fantastic temple. The only down side was in our reading we were supposed to be able to climb to the top but it is all cordoned off.

I visited three times during my first visit to Bangkok (twice during the day and once at night) and each visit had its' own charm.
At night you can roam the grounds around Wat since it is closed, but it is really pretty with lights on and no crowds.
Beautiful temple with so many details in architecture that it leaves you mesmerized.
We were blown away by the size of this place and the amount of work that must have gone into its creation. The level of detail was amazing.
beautiful Wat. Nice little crossover by the ferry for just 4 Baht one way. Admire the details. Must visit.
The shrine was intricately designed and with rich cultural value. Gets crowded in the afternoon, tip is to visit early.
A beautiful construction and a work out at the same time! This is a must see in Bangkok, however, there are some steep steps if you want to climb it.

We visited the temple via the river boat which stops directly outside. It possible to see the temple on the approach but once you get there it’s so much bigger than I expected. Ladies be warn you will not be able enter without your arms and legs covered. As we were not prepared for this we were lucky to discover a stall renting sarongs and shawls for a small charge. The temple is stunningly beautiful and there are plenty of photo opportunities. They are currently exhibiting The Buddha which highlights the misuses of commercialism relating to Buddha in the western world and are asking visitors to sign postcards which will be forward to the suppliers of these goods to try to stop this trading. Easy to spend a good few hours here.
Interesting, unique, beautiful,good for price, nice to visit after getting cheap ferry from Wat Phra Keow, would recommend

column1: Easy to get to and must see while in Bangkok
column3: We stayed down the river and took a boat to this, ask at the boat entrance and they will direct which boat to take. You will pay once you get on the boat so no need to worry about pre buying tickets for the ride. Once there you will have to buy a ticket to enter which was 150 baht if I'm not mistaken. Go inside walk around admire the Temple take some pics and head up the river to the Grand Palace and Reclining Buddha. Enjoy your visit there :)

A beautiful temple right on the river Bangkok. Check it out. And be sure not to miss the smaller Buddha temple next door! Recommend taking a ferry up the river from Sathorn Pier to see a little local flavor on route.
Make sure you tick this off on your bucket list. So much of interest to be seen as you walk around. Photo opportunities galore.

One of the must sees in Bangkok, across the river. Nice atmosphere which changes along with the sunlight - best view around the sunset and the blue hour. Stunnig detail of the stones / bricks in close up view. Be careful when climbing up, they are quite steep but offers great view of surroundings and the river.

This Temple area was quite busy when first getting off the boat but actually when you start walking around it isn't to bad. Nice atmosphere to the place, has a cultural feel to it. I can't remember how much it was to get in but only a few £s.

After you go to The Grand Palace and Wat Pho, ypu must see Wat Arun. Located near The Grand Palace, 10 minutes walk, and take a boat to the other side (price 4 bath).
Wat Arun stands as arguably the most stunning temple in Bangkok because of its riverside location and its dazzling design. Visitors are welcome to climb up to the middle level of the grand pagoda and those that do are rewarded with a beautiful view of the winding Chao Phraya River.
Admission Price 50 bath, cheaper than The Grand Palace and Wat Pho. Wat Arun Ratchawararam meaning Temple of Dawn, the scenery is very beuatifull in sunset, you can enjoy it in Yodpiman River Walk, there are many restaurants that have a direct view to Wat Arun.

Another beautiful landmark.Reach by long tail boat.Pay 30 baht at Pier where you land.Buy entrance fee of 50 baht.
Walk through and you realise it's worth every penny .
Beautiful architecture, work in progress for restoring some area.
Loads of info and statues depicting the culture and history.
Must visit

column1: Beautiful and Intricate. Not a sun-dawn destination though.
column3:
The building/temple is great, tall and pearly but other than that, it's really got nothing else going on. You can't go up because it was closed off (~Jan 2020). There's an entrance fee (can't remember but it's 100baht maybe?).

First impression was a little cooked, I came for the sunrise and I was watching the temple across the river. However, due to weather (super smoggy) and position (i was in parking lot so not that optimal), it was one of the more bland sunrises ever.
It's a great Monument to visit and one can take the ferry from the Wat Pho to this temple. It's only 4 Baht (Jan 2020)

A Beautiful, serene and oldest Temple complex in Bangkok area.

Take Saphan Taksin BTS station and walk towards the central pier to access the boat service. You can either take the public boat which depends on the time of the year might be a long wait. Cost THB 20 per person or take the private option at THB 100 one way or THB 200 for Hop on Hop off.
The last three times I came to see it, it was under construction. This is the first time to see it without scaffolding. Was so beautiful.
This temple is amazing! The whole temple is covered with little pieces of porcelain...There are no words and no pictures who can describe the beauty of this place... you need to see it!
Since, Thailand is mosty Buddist! We decided to visit Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) to get experience about different religions all over the world!
It is amazing place, full of good vibes. Should be visited, early in the morning, when there are not much tourists. At this time you can feel the energy.

column1: Wat Arun, The Temple of Dawn
column3: This is 4th time to step foot on one of the world's most beautiful temples set on the bank of the mighty Chao Praya River. The temple is beautiful specially during sunset and well illuminated bright orange at night. Built in the 17th century and named after Hindu God Aruna. Located in the Thonburi district of the Chao Praya River, you can go here via land transport but for me the best and the fastest way is via boat. Take the BTS and alight at Saphan Taksin station. From here you could take several types of boat but if you're a tourist the most practical way is to take the Chao Praya tourist boat for just 200 Baht, they can take you to different famous landmarks in the Chao Praya river including this beautiful temple. The main feature of the temple is its central tower, Khmer style prang standing about 85 m. It is surrounded by 4 smaller prangs. Made of Porcelain from China, glasses and seashells radiating vibrant white color specially during the day. Khon Guardians also are intricately carved like holding the layers of the temple. Unlike other temples in Thailand, this is a unique design. Ticket for the temple is around 50 baht and it is not too big. Strict dress code is implemented since this is an active Buddhist temple and a Holy ground. It will take you about an hour including your beautiful photos and videos to visit and marvel at the temple itself. The temple has many layers but we've been only up to the 2nd one. Please be mindful the steps are a bit small and steep typical of Khmer architecture. For persons with disability they may not be able to go to the 2nd platform. You can even go further up if you would like to be on the top. Beside the temple is the equally beautiful Ordination hall which has a Buddha statue inside designed by King Rama II. And surrounding the temple is its beautiful park with the monument of King Rama II and it is also a perfect spot to take a panoramic and landmark shot from the base of the temple. Opposite side of the temple across the river there's a boat that could take you to Wat Pho, Temple of Reclining Buddha (separate review). There are many restaurants, cafe and hotels opposite the temple with the grandest view of it. I personally tried eating at Sala Arun with an impeccable view of the temple and it is one of the best moments I had here in Bangkok - such beautiful and relaxing atmosphere indeed.

A beautiful Temple that is very steep and the stairs also. Has the four levels of Reincarnation with the Demons at the bottom and working your way up to Navarna. Beautiful architecture and more amazing pictures. You can walk to or take a boat or car to get there. Go early for it gets very hot

The royal temple of King Rama II with the landmark of the highest prang in Thailand. Aside from the prang as a highlight, the door panel is also magnificent and the boundary stones around the ordination hall are claimed to be the most beautiful ones in Thailand.

This Temple is very cool and conveniently located. The ferry across the river is 4TBH and runs every 5-10 minutes. Dress code is standard for Thai temples (covered shoulders and legs for women) and the entrance fee is 50TBH.

This temple bursts with color and keeps you captivated throughout your time there. It is definitely one of the must see attractions for Bankok. Your trip would not be complete if you missed it. Highly recommended.

Wat Arun was one of the most surprising temples my wife and I visited in Bangkok. We saw it from a distance the night prior, which was beautiful, but you must see the temple up close to truly appreciate the work that went into decorating the site. The grounds are very well maintained, and access is quite simple. We took the ferry from the other side of the river and had no problems at all. The only thing to be aware of is that the stairs are steep and narrow. If you have poor balance be careful getting up and down!

column1: A well maintained and extraordinary place
column3:
I visited here with my wife and in-laws during an off-season. I was very impressed by the stunning workmanship and vivid colors of the pyramids. Despite being off-season a graduation was being celebrated there so there were crowds to deal with, but you could still have good views of the property since much was elevated. There wasn't anything inside that we saw to explore - all features were outside and directly exposed to sun and weather. It was quite warm for us so I expect summers to be nearly unbearable at this site.

Finding a ticket office was a challenge, and the lines for water taxis across the river to Wat Pho greatly interfered with getting on or off them in the morning when we were there. There did not appear to be any special behavior rules at this site.

Still we would recommend that you visit here if in Bangkok. It's worth dealing with some crowds.

Wat Arun is one of the popular sites in Bangkok and with good reason. It’s stunning. Clad in millions of ceramics.
Standing close to the river it can be reached by water taxi.
Good at sunset. Has market stalls near to get souvenirs etc. worth spending a couple of hours here.
Beautiful temple and great place for some" kodak"moments. The temple has lots of interesting details and you can spend hours discovering more about it
A really very lovely temple on the other side of the river. Access by boat is nice. Than thousands of ceramic cups.. superb!!!!

It is a beautiful temple, located at the other side of the river of the grand palace. You get the boat to cross the river from the grand palace and reclining Buddha temple.
The architecture and the colors of the temple are magnificent.

My third time to this temple and still one of the steepest stairs to walk on. Seeing the great view is very peaceful. The architectural design is very beautiful. The shape and the color compliments each other.

Been to the top of this temple twice, but this year they closed it. I think it's because this is so steep to climb and a bit dangerous for children and old people.

Still one of the best temples to explore in Bangkok.
A very beautiful temple, worth visiting. However I would recommend where possible to enter as early as you can. It gets very busy during the day.
Great view of this temple from other side of Chao Praya river. We will be back for the views, especially at night.

Not much to say about this stunning temple except that, boasting gorgeous architecture and lovely river views, it is definitely worth a visit. I arrived by train and on foot - the temple can be reached by an approximately 1.2km walk from Itsaraphap MRT Station, located on the Blue Line. I left by boat, which was incredibly cheap and conveniently dropped me at Wat Pho by the Grand Palace on the opposite side of the river. I recommend visiting around or shortly before sunset, as in my opinion it lends an even more picturesque quality to an already stunning piece of architecture. Make sure you put it on your must-see list!
Wat Arun or The Temple of Dawn is the one of my beautiful temples in Thailand. Decorated with chinese ceramic porcelains are stunning.

The main part of the temple is like what you can see on photos. And it looks a lot smaller when you are there seeing it! It is still a very unique building though but one probably needs only 15 - 20 minutes max to walk around the main part.

The actual highlight is the temple around the main building. It is worh spendng 30 minutes after visiting the main building to walk around the site as there are at least 2 other temples with monks and worshipers.

Wat Arun, or the Temple of Dwan, is among the best known landmarks in Bangkok. It dates back to the 17th century. Its name derives from the first light of the morning that reflect off the surface of the temple which is encrusted with colorful porcelain. The Buddhist temple is easily approachable by boat through the Chao Phraya River. When visiting please adhere to the attire policy (covered knees, no shorts). The entrance is 50 Baht (approximately $1.65).
Beautiful breathtaking place. A must visit place. Approachable thru boats. Walk around and you will enjoy the beauty. Being a religious place, please put covered dress.
It is just what you see, absolutely stunning in perfect location which is by the river, especially in the night time scene

The temple has been beautifully maintained and it’s entry is very reasonable in comparison to other attractions near by! Easy access through the use of the hop on hop off boat as well. This was an enjoyable stop on our day exploring along the river.

Seeing the temple Of Dawn across the river at Ambrose at Sunset id magical!

Next morning visiting Wat Arun close up is amazing. So many details with magnificent architecture! A must to visit from fat and close by absolutely magnificent!

Years ago I visited all the temples in Bangkok except Wat Arun and I think this is one of the most unique and beautiful temple in Bangkok.

To get here we took the MRT/BTS from Sukhumvit and stopped at What Pho, the trick is you can walk for 5 minute from Wat Pho and take the boat crossing the river to Wat Arun for 5 BAHT!

Remember to wear outfit that don’t shown your arms and more than knee length to enter the temple.

The main temple was beautiful but also their monk hall located next to the temple, I suggest to visit early in the morning when it’s still quite and not many tourist around.

Intricately decorated and difficult to climb but you can't go all the way to the top because they had closed the top for renovation I guest. The temple is impressive and distinctive from most Thai temples. It's worth seeing it.
this is a beautiful temple and must visit when in bangkok. this is only 50 baht to enter and we enjoyed exploring thus area and walking up the steep stairs for the viewpoint

Not only to climb up to huge pagoda, around the temple you can feel calm and relax or up to meditation which I almost do it every time.
wat Arun not only place to visit but it once in a lifetime

column1: Good as a temple at Sunset!
column3: Probably best seen as part of a guided tour. Is across the Chao Phraya from the Palace and the majority of the famous temple complexes and is a good place to finish your tour. Beautiful decorative porcelain work. Quite steep, so is quite arduous at the end of a long afternoon temple hopping. Pier 8 will receive boats to drop you and take you back from the Wat.

column1: Another must visit when in Bangkok
column3: We visited after the Grand Palace. Easy to get to via 1 min river crossing. Large temple and you can walk up some of the lower level parts. A lot less busy/hectic than the Grand Palace which was suprising and made for a more pleasant experience.
A wonderful place, you do not want to miss. Also known as the The Temple of Reclining Buddha, this temple is an absolute must when visiting Bangkok
Very nice temple. When I went their the temple was closed.. And prayer was going on..Timing is 8am to 6 pm..So i watch the temple from outside.

Ticket cost 50 baht for foreigner
Proper cloth is advised, or you can rent some cloth near the entrance/ticket booth

Of all the wats I saw in Bangkok and Chiang Mai, this was my favorite. This is a unique wat in that it is covered with broken bits of tile and pottery salvaged from a British shipwreck! You go up to the walls and literally see little soy sauce dishes and broken Chinese plates formed into flowers and patterns. We did not go inside the wat - I believe you can go inside the central prang - but we were able to climb partway up the spire using the outdoor steps and see a nice view of the city. If you only see one wat in Bangkok, make it this one!

column1: Gorgeous by day and by night
column3: The temple complex is gorgeous. We visited early in the day and enjoyed the site with very few people around. The site has plenty to see and by night the lights in this place makes for a unique site.
Amazing temple. The cost was only 2€, it has a strict dress code which you have to follow unless you rent dresses with some cost in order to enter. A must visit, especially whe the sun goes down

column1: Beautiful place to visit and admire the beauty.
column3: The tile work is amazing. The place is very small compared to other temples in Bangkok. But we were glad to go there because simply it was pretty
One of those "must see" temples in Bangkok. It was stunning and i think only 50 baht entry fee which is cheap (Grand Palace was 500 baht). Also lovely to see it from across the river.
To get here, we have to take a boat across chaophraya river. There is a lot of monks praying when I went there because almost new year time.

column1: River cruise is the best way
column3: Every time I have overseas visitors coming from abroad I always take them on a dinner river cruise which passes the Temple of the Dawn. it is most spectacular to take a picture from the boat that floats in the middle of the river. You get the whole view of the Temple all lit up, it is so magical I highly recommend.

The Wat Arun is much more than pictures can justify. The sheer size, color, and carvings on the temple leave you awestruck the moment you see it from close. A definite visit on a Bangkok trip.

We reached here using a ferry near Wat Pho which cost us only 5 baht per person for one side.

One can visit the temple and roam around the premises in whatever they are wearing. In order to get inside the temple, one should carry clothes covering elbows and knees.

I came a few times to visit and it's always a great option.
It would be great to find more dining option around it
A Bangkok must. To see these for the first time you are just awe struck. You need about an hour here. We used the the Hop on Hop off ferry boat to get to here.

column1: Nice temple to visit in the morning.
column3: We had a bit of a time finding the ferry to take us over to Wat Arun, but it was exactly where they tell you it is. It just doesn't appear as though you should go down that street. Beautiful temple. Definitely recommend a visit in the morning as it's cooler and less crowds.

Have done grand palace before but missed this place so decided to visit. Was very busy day but this did not distract from taking in the beauty and architecture of this place. Spent a hour wandering around and hiking up and down the steps. It was a very hot day and think I lost 6lb in sweat but loved every minute
Beautiful Temple which is made from ceramic in white color. Nice place to visit in Bangkok and to take pictures. If you have a river cruse on night you will see it yellow by the lights
A must visit. Looks like just same in the card postals. In the evening looks more stunning.So; two bisits would be better.

column1: Two visits day and night... worth it....
column3: The gold color with many inlay colors and the soaring central tower and the four corners of towers makes for quite a site. We then observed it by going back and forth on the ferry at night as well as the hop on - hop off boat along the river.

Amazing detailed temple, visit when the sun sets. Wonderful colours.
The colour of this temple is different from all the rest in Thailand, well worth seeing

Despite our high season (early January) visit we had a reasonable tour of the temple proper, an adjacent shrine, some time to hydrate and a bit of trinket shopping in one hour.

The second level is reached by a number of wide and steep (but not hideously so) staircases. There are no railings but there are ledges at each side you can use if necessary for some balance. The walkway around is narrow but people can pass and there are wide places at corners. The "selfie" crowd was reasonably subdued and I was able to get some very nice if very quickly composed photos with my SLR without causing disruption.

The entire temple is covered in decoration--much of it floral--made using mainly ordinary household objects of boldly decorated porcelain. Sadly there are many broken pieces on the two lowest levels but the upper levels (closed off) are nearly pristine.

If you get a hop-on/hop-off river pass you MUST stop here! 30 minutes is possible if you rush.

I liked Wat Arun the first time and it deserved a 2nd visit. With no glitz nor dazzling golden adornments, the Temple of Dawn distinguishes itself with its tall elegant structures, and pastel tones. Old multi coloured porcelain crockery were used to embellish its exterior, a bit reminiscent of Gaudi’s broken tile embellishments in Park Guell.
As it takes about 35 by car to get there from town, the crowds are thinner, a plus point. We spent a few hours at Icon Siam mall, 15 minutes away, so that we could be at Wat Arun for sunset. The temple closes at 6pm.
If you visit the Grand Palace and Wat Pho across the river, go to a restaurant next to the river, as the view of Wat Arun is magnificent. This Bangkok landmark is a must see.

column1: Iconic Temple by the Chao Phraya River
column3: My Thai hosts took me on a trip down the Chao Phraya River by river taxi - very cheap, if you can distinguish them from the more expensive, tourist boats. I am sure the best way to approach Wat Arun is from the river, as you see its gleaming spires from afar. It was mighty hot when we were there - over 40%, and the Sunday crowds were searching for shade, as were we! The steps can be pretty steep, and the sun reflects brightly off the white and brightly painted glazed walls of the temple. It only costs 50 baht to enter what is probably the most iconic Buddhist temple in Bangkok, 250 years old and still in excellent condition. A must see, and approach from the river, if you can!
Loved this temple. Got there via the river and explored the surrounds too. It’s such a lovely place to see

Beautiful temple but it did not take long to walk around. There are small markets outside and tours for the ferry. Watch out for the scamming tuk-tuk drivers though, they will lead you to believe the temples are closed for lunch and convince you to go on a tour with them.
we stayed on the river and were always looking at wat arun as a beacon to our eyes and whereabouts...

This temple is a must see. We also took the boat to cross the river - only 4 Bht.
The stairs might be too steep for elderly or unstable.

Amazing old temple area, with many many golden budhas in it!
Easy to go there with local boat which was very cheap too (only 15 bath)or ferry from Wat po, (only 4 bath).

column1: Take a riverboat to Temple Of Dawn
column3:
This is my absolute favorite temple! The first time I saw it in 1973
It was covered in scaffolding and lovingly restored; I could see it’s beauty even so!
I have revisited several times and it never fails to bring a tear to my eye because I was on R&R with my brave beautiful husband
here and this gorgeous place never fails to bring me a renewal of spirit just as did the first time so long ago!
A beautiful monument that everyone should visit at least once, both locals and foreigners should enjoy a picturesque day at Wat Arun.

I truly believe that this temple is one of the most magnificent places in Bangkok, visit it during daylight and then go for a romantic dinner cruise on the Chao Phraya River (remember to be seated out in the open) in the evening and see it again. It drags me every time I'm in Bangkok and it's hard to find a word that fully cover this experience.

When visiting Temple of the Dawn, be sure to go to the beautiful temple and courtyards in the back away from the river. First of all you will have the peace of leaving the crowds behind, and you will find stunning courtyard with granite “Chinese ballast” carvings and an array of Buddha’s, rescued by the king from outlying temples, and an elegant Thai style temple and Buddha with ornate Chinese artwork.
Don’t miss this peaceful detour!
Wat Arun is not your typical Thai temple. It is more of a beautiful monument. Undoubtedly fantastic back-drop for photo taking. Highly recommended to visit when in Bangkok.
This is a highlight of any trip to Bangkok. Gorgeous and moving at any time of day. Just remember to wear (or take) something to cover bare shoulders and legs.
Very beautiful place to take pictures. It was a hot day make sure to bring an umbrella. It is good if you go right when they open. In the afternoon it is crowded of turists.

An other culture place where you must to be. A lot of history behind this place that was build from Mata IV if I don't get wrong how wanted to improve the magnificent of this city. And he did it. The temple is huge and very well done with a lot of details, you can feel the culture inside of it and you cannot regret to be there one time in lifetime at least.
This is a very beautiful temple that should be viewed both during the day and at night. Beware, it's very crowded so pack a little patience.
It was beautiful place to visit, would go there again when I visit Bangkok. We had fun and took a lot of pictures.

We started with Wat Pho and hopped on the ferry to get over the river to see this wat. The ferry is very easy to find, cost 4bth one way and was not a problem at all. I don’t understand some of the reviews that say got ripped off on this ride or couldn’t find it. Just get out of Wat Pho at the back (the river side), turn right and where the shops end turn left. Vua la:-)
The wat Arun is still under repair so you cannot climb to the top which would have been cool. Entrance 50 bath. We were done in 30 mins. Our 6yo enjoyed both wats and the river ferry.
I have a chance to watch Wat Arun from a private boat. This place is gorgeous at night. I would recommend seeing on the boat or another side if you have a chance.
Stunning temple! A must see in Bangkok! You take a ferry to cross the river. That experience in itself is a must do.

It was great to see Wat Arun again recently near Christmas and getting there earlier in the day meant that my friend and I avoided the rush of crowds descending upon the beloved attraction and somewhat impairing its sense of tranquility.

We saw this wat at night from a restaurant across the river. It was brilliantly lit up and it was necessary for us to visit it. We arrived during the day on the hop-on, hop-off ferry, which I recommend highly. The golden Buddha image and the dais is well worth seeing. The wat was built primarily in the style of Rama III who used the ceramic pieces of broken dishwear coming from China to decorate the stupas and other exteriors. See photos. Also well worth seeing. Lots of tourists and lots of stairs, but an excellent attraction to visit.

This temple is beautiful but we were there on a holiday (Fathers Day) so it was very crowded. We didn't opt for the additional fee to go in, but there was another interesting building just next door that was free. We were doing the "Hop on/Hop of" Chaya Prao boat ride that afternoon.

One of the loveliest temples in Bangkok. A good place to marvel at the Thai architecture and spend good 2-3 hours. Very well connected with Wat Pho via boat or you can take MRT which is only 10 minutes walk from the temple (assuming you want to avoid the Bangkok traffic and not travel in taxi).

Very beautiful temple. It will be good to have details about the temple's history written otherwise you have to rely on guides or do your research in advance.
We went there after Wat Pho with local boat ( 4 Bath/p) it was fun. You can go around the temple an go up "first floor". There is a very nice view.

This is another breath taking moment in Bangkok. So beautiful and stunning. Get there by water taxi or the hop on hop off tourist boat from Central Pier, underneath the BTS Sky Train stop. 200 baht for a whole day pass, so you can see lots of other sights too. The piers are chaotic but go with the flow, it all sorts itself out! Wat Arun is just incredible, well worth the effort.

The Wat Arun temple is most easily accessed from the Tha Thien pier (near the Wat Pho temple and the Royal Palace). The Royal Palace can be accessed from the recently opened Sanam Chai Metro station. The visit to this temple is well worth the trip, which can be combined with the visit to the Royal Palace or the Wat Pho temple (any of these three attractions should not be missed while in Bangkok!).

column1: Land mark icon of Bangkok, by the chao phraya river
column3:
Use the ferry to get to Wat Arun from the meeting cross of Grand palace and Wat Pho. Not much to see inside as its all closed but you can observe the structure and building up close.
The night view of this place is great as viewed from Cruise
It’s good place to visit here but during rainy time is not too convenient to visit this place, and need raincoat or umbrella

This temple is certainly worth a visit. We went around noon so it was crowded but still manageable to get a good viewing perspective. Make sure to wander the grounds as there is more to see than just the main ‘big’ temple.

It’s a nice temple to visit but you don’t get inside , only around it. Stew steps but only a few. Not accessible.
Best way is to get the shuttle boat services

On the banks of Chao Phraya, this is a historic temple famous for its beautiful carvings. The temple is next to the Grand palace separated by the river and can be visited alongwith the grand palace on the same circuit.

The Buddhas here are very hospitable. The place is very clean with a magnificent view from the Bangkok river. Everyone is friendly and helpful. The history is amazing for this temple. It has a very beautiful scenery at night. I encourage to visit at dawn
Like other temples in Bangkok, Wat Arun is marvellous and different from most of the other temples..
One of the most beautiful temple in bangkok. The architecture is fantastic. I liked this temple the most. Every view/corner is amazingly beautiful.

There are certainly more aesthetically pleasing temples in Bangkok, as this one didn’t necessarily stand out to us. It is colorful and beautiful, but if you only had time to visit one temple, this would not be my recommendation.

For such a historic and recognizable site, there sure are a lot of unknowns. We don’t know how old it is, because its years of construction are not recorded. But the temple definitively existed by the mid-1600s. Even the precise height can’t be agreed upon, as reports vary by 63 feet!

Small pieces of porcelain were painstakingly attached to the towers, which is rather impressive. The site obviously has religious significance to some, which should be respected. But it wasn’t our favorite stop in Bangkok. If you have time, stop by for a visit. If you don’t have time, I’d skip it.

Again, another amazing place to see in Bangkok. the temple is amazing and interesting to look at. There is cloth restrictions like other temples, you must wear something to cover your ankles and shoulders. The entrance fee is cheaper than Grand Palace, 50 Baht per person. 1 hour is enough to see and there are local shops around the temple so you can buy souvenir.
A must visit for tourists to Bangkok. The only thing to remember is how busy this temple can get, I would suggest earlier rather than later to avoid the crowds. So impressive.

The first time I came here was in 2008 , figure I’d go back for the view but unfortunately the top level is now closed off. Also odd is the string tied just over ones head around most of the base area. It gets in the way of photos and I’m not sure of the purpose.

I suggest anyone to see wat Arun by night from the river or some terrace just opposite it ,is when u get to enjoy it more as its illuminated and you can see the beauty it has
I got to see it twice one from one terrace in front of it at the Riva Arun Bangkok hotel in the last floor and second one the best one from the cruise boat
Wat Aran was magnificent; it was larger and grander than I expected. Definitely a not to miss sightseeing destination in Bangkok. Less crowded in the morning before the tour buses arrive.

column1: One of the must visit lamdmarks around and very cheap
column3: A good temple to visit on any day, greater if there are lesser tourist around where you can enjoy or explore the temple quietly. 50 baht entrance fee. Offers ferry to Iconsiam at 60 baht per trip. There are also boats for temple hopping.
This is possibly the most beautiful temple I have ever seen. It has been beautifully crafted and when lit up at night, it is stunning.

well the place is called the temple of dawn dedicated to lord Sun. It is quite a huge place if you consider the entire compound. it is very intricately carved and takes THB 50 for the entrance.

Tips: Be careful of the dress (no shorts), view in the evening time is marvelous, there are lot of souvenir shops inside the compound....

Just over the river from Wat Pho temple,easily crossed by boat cost 15 THB per person and the entry fee is 50 THB.Be aware of the dress code,no shorts and covered shoulders though they will rent you covers if you need one.The temple itself is very ornate with mosaics covering much of the building,you can climb up the steps on the outside a little way but they are very steep.Worth a visit but not a long one.
Just beautiful these sites are extraordinarily beautiful and need to be seen with your own eyes the details

This is a small but beautiful place. You need to go over on the boat but you can do this on a water ferry and not a tourist trip

Near Icon Siam which is a nice shopping mall with a streetfood basement and a 3 starred michelin restaurant (but not sure if that is true as did not see what the restaurant was like)

You will need to cover your legs in certain parts
The wat is so gorgeous and very detailed. It will be awesome is less crowded but generally speaking it is great.

column1: A temple that is a sight for the eyes and the soul.
column3: The arrival of Wat Arun by boat already warns the visitor of the spectacle that awaits him. The temple is wonderful with mosaic masterpieces in its various buildings. Entering the temple, meditating, and receiving a monk's blessing transports you to another world of faith and well-being for the soul.
you pay entrance fee but not that much, the sight is very nice and highly recommended if you visit Bangkok.

Very beautiful architecture a must visit place if you love architects. Don’t forget to wear long dress and not showing your shoulders else you have to rent saraong which is 20 bhat and / or 50 bhat and also have to deposit money which is refundable but that is all wastage of money. column1: Stunning by day and by night
column3:
Wat Arun, is a 'must see' for anyone visiting Bangkok. My wife and I visited as part of an "Introduction to Bangkok" Tour, operated by Exo Travel Thailand. We pre-booked this with our Travel Agent, Trailfinders, prior to leaving the UK and that was worth doing. Our guide picked us up at our hotel and took us around the city, using various modes of transport, and visiting all of the most important sightseeing places. His knowledge of every place visited was invaluable, and saved us having to stop regularly to read up on the history of each place.

Although the central Prang is stunning, and the main feature in Wat Arun, there are other parts worth seeing. such as the main Chapel and the Ordination Hall. Wat Arun is normally visited during daylight hours, it is worth returning at night, if only to take photos when it is lit up. My wife and I were able to do that, as we booked a second tour, also with Exo, that included 'Bangkok by Night' and a riverside dinner. This gave us the chance to take photos in both daylight and nighttime and I will upload photos of both.

This is why going with a knowledgeable guide is such an advantage, as the names and history of each part are explained to you, saving invaluable time if you wish to visit other popular sights on the same day.

In Thai the word Wat translates to temple and Arun means dawn. Thus this temple is known in English as the Temple of Dawn. This is a very popular attraction for many tourists along with the Grand Palace which is located directly across the river from Wat Arun by downtown Bangkok. To get to Wat Arun you will need to board a ferry to take you across the river. The easiest way to get to one would be to board the Bangkok Transit System (BTS) and get off on the Saphan Taksin ferry stop. From there it is around 25 minutes via boat to Wat Arun with some stops along the way. There will be signs at the dock listing tourist boats but beware that many will try to overcharge. For two individuals you shouldn’t pay more than 100 THB one way. If you choose to board at a different location they may charge upwards of 350 THB per person in locations near the Grand Palace. If you are near there we suggest walking down 10 minutes to the Tha Thien ferry station and pay 4 THB per person instead. Once you arrive you will purchase an entry ticket for 50 THB and if you are not dressed properly they will allow you to rent a sarong for 20 THB with a 100 THB refundable deposit. Generally you should wear long pants and avoid showing open shoulders but they can be lenient at times. Once inside you are free to roam around but there will be security there who will warn you if you are doing something you aren’t supposed to. This is mainly to protect the temple as many people tend to climb on the structures to get a good picture. We highly advise visiting here especially If you are torn between this and the Grand Palace.

We got the ferry from the grounds of the temple to the other side of the river after we finished.
Worth the visit for sure.

This is smaller than the temples in and around the Grand Palace, but it is so peaceful and extremely beautiful inside, that I encourage you to visit if you have time. You must cross a river with a ferry / boat to get there, which is very inexpensive, and was not too difficult to find. It is walkable from the Grand Palace, but not right next-door. You must take your shoes off to enter the temple. It was an active, working temple with monks praying and doing things in and around it. We got stuck on the premises during a huge monsoon, and everyone was very gracious to let us wait it out.

As the temple is the other side of the river from Wat Pho or the Grand Palace, you need to walk a bit, then use the boat / ferry (it costs 4 baht to one direction). It takes longer to wait than to cross.
The temple is amazing, really as beautiful as in the pictures. We weren't allow to climb to the top, just until the first 'floor'. We took lots of pictures. You can just sit there for a while and enjoy the beauty of its structure, the different tiles.
The entrance ticket was 50 bahts but they advised that from July it will cost 100 bahts for foreigners.

This is one of the many temples in Bangkok - I think it was the most stunning. You have to take a short boat journey across the river to get to it! Looks very pretty before sunset, and there are great views of it at night!
A must visit when you are in Bangkok. It is very beautiful. Has a lot of different gods in the temple. Very easy to reach. Can use water taxi or MRT.

We visited the temple in February and were amazed by the size of the temple and the work that must have gone into building this stunning temple. It is well worth a visit and you will not be dissapointed.

Wat Arun is a Buddhist temple in Bangkok (west bank of the Chao Phraya River). The Temple of the Dawn towering over the Chao Phraya River is one of Bangkok’s most visually striking landmarks and also one of Thailand’s top attractions. The temple was built in 17th century in the era of the Ayutthaya Kingdom. The temple’s name has taken from the Hindu god “Aruna”.
The temple’s central prang stands 79 meters tall and is decorated with tiny pieces of colored glittery glass. The first rays of the morning sun in Bangkok appear on the surface of the temple vividly.
If you don’t want to be stuck in the crowd and you want to take full pleasure of the sunrise in the temple go there as soon as possible. You must wear respectable clothes for entering the holy temple, otherwise you have to pay money to borrow suitable clothes from the temple’s entrance.
Wat Arun can be easily accessed through the Chao Phraya River by taxi boats which travel across the river. If you take a longtail boat tour for visiting Bangkok, you can see both Wat Arun and Bangkok’s other top attractions such as Chinatown, Wat Phra Kaew, Grand Palace and the Wat Pho, as you cruising the Chao Phraya River. Visiting of this really magnificent temple is highly recommended.

column1: Well worth the 4 baht ferry across the river
column3: We had been to the Grand Palace and Wat Pho, and we had to cross the river to see Wat Arun. It is a huge structure which seems largely ceramic. Because of the lack of other tourists we were able to get unobstructed views of the Temple and the Grand Palace on the other side of the river.

The Grand Palace has been the most favourite temple in Bangkok for most tourists; however, Temple of Dawn might have been a favourite temple for some due to uniquely designed structure. The temple can be reached by boat, the most convenient way.
With all the sights and variety this Temple has a good feel to it Not sure why but it touched me upon entering

The Temple of Dawn was an incredibly impressive monument to visit. The detail of the architecture was stunning and it actually doesn't matter what time you go, you'll enjoy it. Having said that, catching a glimpse at dusk is one to marvel at.
I went here with my Malaysian friends. This was my first time visiting temple. I enjoyed my day there.

Amazing place to visit. Our guide Tony knew so much of the history and helped us to appreciate the beauty of this sacred place.
